sen.j: 広沢 安任（ひろさわ やすとう、文政13年2月2日 (旧暦)（1830年2月24日） - 明治24年（1891年）2月5日）は、江戸時代後期、幕末期の会津藩士。
sen.e: Yasuto HIROSAWA (February 24 (February 2, according to the old calendar), 1830 - February 5, 1891) was a feudal retainer of the Aizu clan (now Fukushima Prefecture) during the late Edo period, the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate.
Yasuto HIROSAWA (February 24, 1830 - February 5, 1891) was a feudal retainer of the Aizu clan (now Fukushima Prefecture) lived in the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate during the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 基本的に日時は旧暦から直すルールだったと思います。このため旧暦については削除しました。訳文はbe動詞と時期のみでしたが、「during」を用いていますので「〜の期間に」「何をしていた」と動作を加えました。コンマで接続された最後の分節を、語順変更により分節化せず一文化しました。
sen.e: Yasuto HIROSAWA (February 24, 1830 - February 5, 1891) was a feudal retainer of the Aizu clan (now Fukushima Prefecture) lived in the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate during the late Edo period.
He was a child of Shosuke HIROSAWA

sen.cmt: 文末にピリオドが欠けていましたので追加しています。
sen.e: He was a child of Shosuke HIROSAWA.

sen.j: 通称が富次郎のため、広沢 富次郎の名で知られる。
sen.e: Because his common name was Tomijiro, he was widely known in the name of Tomijiro HIROSAWA.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）、会津藩主松平容保は京都守護職に任ぜられ、広沢は先んじて上京し京都の情勢を探った。
sen.e: In 1862, the appointment of his Lord of Aizu domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA as Kyotoshugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto, to counteract the growing Sonno Joi (the 19th century slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners) movement, which was centered in Kyoto) brought HIROSAWA to Kyoto earlier in order to search for the movement of anti shogunate extremist samurai there.
sen.cmt: 京都守護職→to counteract the growing Sonno Joi (the 19th century slogan advocateing reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners) movement, which was centered in Kyoto)を補足しました
sen.e: In accordance with the appointment of the Aizu domain Lord Katamori MATSUDAIRA as Kyotoshugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto, to counteract the growing Sonno Joi (the 19th century slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners, which was centered in Kyoto) in 1862, HIROSAWA moved to Kyoto in advance to the arrival of the lord Katamori in order to investigate the situation of Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 1. 原文の2文構成を受動形「brought HIROSAWA to〜」としていますが、特に括弧による説明も長く主語と離れるため、あまり良い用法ではないと思います。語順を変え修正しました。2. 訳者は意訳して広沢の京都での情勢探索を「倒幕運動の動きを探る」としていますが、多少意訳しすぎていると判断し、原文にあわせ、京都の情勢を探ったという文章にしました。
sen.e: In accordance with the appointment of the Aizu domain Lord Katamori MATSUDAIRA as Kyotoshugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto, to counteract the growing Sonno Joi (the 19th century slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners, which was centered in Kyoto) in 1862, HIROSAWA moved to Kyoto in advance to the arrival of the lord Katamori in order to investigate the situation of Kyoto.

sen.j: 容保上京後は公用方に任ぜられ、公卿、諸藩士、新選組などと交流を持った。
sen.e: After Katamori's arrival in Kyoto, HIROSAWA was assigned to koyokata (the section of local domain which is in charge of dealing with all works related to the bakufu central government and the Imperial seat) to promote interactions with Kugyo (Court nobles), feudal retainers of domains, and Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa shogunate).
sen.cmt: 新撰組→(a group who guareded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa shogunate)を補足しました

After Katamori's arrival in Kyoto, HIROSAWA was assigned to koyokata (the section of local domain which is in charge of dealing with all works related to the bakufu central government and the Imperial seat) to promote interactions with Kugyo (Court nobles), feudal retainers of domains, and Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa shogunate).

sen.j: 鳥羽・伏見の戦いの後、江戸そして会津に戻った容保らの立場を新政府に嘆願するため、江戸に残ったが新政府軍に投獄された。
sen.e: After the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, he remained in Edo (present Tokyo) to plead with the restoration government to fully understand and respect the stand of Katamori, who had returned to Edo and Aizu, but was imprisoned by the new government army.

After the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, he remained in Edo (present Tokyo) to plead with the restoration government to understand the situation of Katamori returning to Edo and Aizu, but he was imprisoned by the new government army.
sen.cmt: 多少意訳につながる修飾語などを削除し、簡略化しました。
sen.e: After the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, he remained in Edo (present Tokyo) to plead with the restoration government to understand the situation of Katamori returning to Edo and Aizu, but he was imprisoned by the new government army.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）釈放され、斗南に減封移封された後廃藩置県により小参事となった広沢は貧困に苦しんでいた会津藩士のため谷地頭（現在の三沢市）に洋式牧場を開設し地域の発展に尽くした。
sen.e: Released in 1869, he promoted regional growth; he became a junior councilor of Tonami Prefecture (now part of Aomori Prefecture) established by the Act of the new government, Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), and exploited pastures in the Western style in Yachigashira (present Misawa City) for many retainers of the Aizu clan suffering from poverty because Aizu Domain was diminished and transferred to wasteland Tonami before Haihan-chiken, so that they relocated there.

After released by the government in 1869, he devoted himself to promote regional growth; when he became a junior councilor of Tonami Prefecture (soon incorporated into Aomori Prefecture) established by Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures enacted by new government), he exploited Western style pastures in Yachigashira (present Misawa City) for those retainers of the Aizu clan suffering from extreme poverty since the reduction and transfer of Aizu Domain to a wasteland Tonami as Tonami clan (reorganized as Tonami Prefecture and soon incorporated into Aomori Prefecture by Haihan-chiken).
sen.cmt: 原文がまずく特に文頭部分は主語がはっきりしていません。「斗南に減封ーされた後」の主語は「会津藩」と思われ広沢ではありませんが後の文章に繋がっています。訳者はこの部分を説明するためかなりの文章を加えていますが、それでも多少わかりづらいものとなっています。この点留意して修正を加えました。
